div.head: Excellent tempering for breastplates
div.ab: Take river water, as clear & running as possible, & heat it to a little more than tepid. Then take a bunch of weld, & take the seed of it & put it into the said water & boil it thoroughly, stirring it with a stick, then pour it into a muid or any other vessel, then throw into it two pecks of salt.

Then take a big cauldron full of the said river water & heat it up slightly more than warm. & Take three or four times the quantity of red greasy earth, three or four double handfuls, wet it & throw it into the cauldron with the said water. Take as much pigeon dung as of the said earth, & as much horse dung & as much iron filings. & wet the whole separately, & throw it into the caldron & leave it for two or three days. Then throw it after into the said muid and stir the whole thoroughly together. And the older this tempering liquid is, the better it will be.

div.head: Varnish for distemper
div.ab: You can make marble by distemper from lake or rose of Ghent & chalk. Once dry, glaze with lake mixed in wine, for the glue makes it die & blacken. And all will then appear red, but the varnish you will put here, which will penetrate, will make dark & light parts appear as they ought to be. The varnish is made thus, mix with clear Venice turpentine some spike lavender oil & until all is clear & liquid enough, &it is done without fire. This one es is for things in distemper, and the turpentine varnish that you know, for panels. Pure spike lavender oil varnish is not good for panels, for spike lavender oil is too penetrating & makes colours sparkle, unless it was made long ago.
